description:
Acronicta aceris, commonly known as the Sycamore Dagger Moth, is a species of moth belonging to the family Noctuidae. This species is native to Europe and parts of Asia, and it derives its name from its preferred host plant, the sycamore tree (Acer pseudoplatanus).

The Sycamore Dagger Moth has a wingspan of approximately 35-45 millimeters. Its forewings are greyish-brown in color, often with distinctive dark patches and white markings, giving it a camouflaged appearance that helps it blend in with the bark of its host plant. The hindwings are typically pale grey or whitish.

The larvae, or caterpillars, of the Sycamore Dagger Moth are distinctive, with a dark-colored body covered in tufts of hair. They feed on the leaves of the sycamore tree, as well as other maple species (Acer spp.), and can occasionally become a pest in urban and suburban areas where sycamore trees are common.

The species undergoes a complete metamorphosis, with the larvae pupating in the soil or leaf litter before emerging as adult moths in the spring or summer months. The Sycamore Dagger Moth is generally considered a common and widespread species throughout its range, playing a role in the ecosystem as a pollinator and as a food source for various predators.
